If sons and daughters of good family who abide in the vehicle of bodhisattvas, when practicing the perfection of wisdom without skillful means, regard form as empty and become attached to the notion of emptiness, regard feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness as empty and become attached to the notion of emptiness;

if they regard the eye sense base as empty and become attached to the notion of emptiness, regard the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases as empty and become attached to the notion of emptiness;

if they regard the ear element as empty and become attached to the notion of emptiness;

If one regards the nose element as empty, one gives rise to the notion of emptiness and becomes attached to it, and regards the smell element, the nose consciousness element, and the nose contact, the sensory activity field of nose contact as empty, one gives rise to the notion of emptiness and becomes attached to it;

If one regards internal emptiness as empty and gives rise to attachment to the notion of emptiness, and regards external emptiness, internal and external emptiness, emptiness of emptiness, great emptiness, ultimate emptiness, emptiness of conditioned phenomena, emptiness of unconditioned phenomena, absolute emptiness, emptiness without beginning or end, emptiness of separation, emptiness of inherent existence, emptiness of intrinsic nature, emptiness of all phenomena, emptiness of non-apprehension, emptiness of nature, emptiness of intrinsic nature, and emptiness of the intrinsic nature of non-existence as empty, giving rise to attachment to the notion of emptiness;ğŸ”½If one regards suchness as empty and gives rise to attachment to the notion of emptiness, and regards the dharma realm, dharma nature, non-false nature, unchanging nature, equality, nature of separation from birth, dharma determination, abiding in the dharma, reality limit, space element, and inconceivable element as empty, giving rise to attachment to the notion of emptiness;

If the sons and daughters of good family who abide in the vehicle of the bodhisattvas, using skillful means with something to attain, from their initial generation of the mind up to the perfection of giving give rise to the notion of practice, and give rise to the notion of practice regarding the perfections of morality, patience, vigor, concentration, and wisdom;

If one gives rise to the notion of practice and attachment to internal emptiness, to external emptiness, to internal and external emptiness, to the emptiness of emptiness, to great emptiness, to ultimate emptiness, to conditioned emptiness, to unconditioned emptiness, to absolute emptiness, to emptiness without beginning or end, to emptiness of dispersion, to emptiness of immutability, to emptiness of inherent nature, to emptiness of specific characteristics, to emptiness of common characteristics, to emptiness of all dharmas, to emptiness of non-attainment, to emptiness of nature, to emptiness of self-nature, and to emptiness of the nature of non-existence;

If one gives rise to the notion of practice and attachment to suchness, to the dharma realm, to the dharma nature, to non-falsehood, to immutability, to equality, to the nature of non-arising, to the determination of dharmas, to the abiding of dharmas, to the reality limit, to the space element, and to the inconceivable element;

If one gives rise to the notion of practice and attachment to the noble truth of suffering, to the noble truth of the accumulation [of suffering], to the noble truth of the cessation [of suffering], and to the noble truth of the path [to the cessation of suffering];
If one gives rise to the notion of practice and attachment to the four concentrations, to the four immeasurables, and to the four formless concentrations;
If one becomes attached to the idea of practice regarding the eight liberations, the eight spheres of mastery, the nine successive concentrations, and the ten universal bases;

If one becomes attached to the idea of practice regarding the gate of liberation through emptiness, the gate of liberation through signlessness, and the gate of liberation through wishlessness;
If one becomes attached to the idea of practice regarding the ten grounds of the bodhisattva;
If one becomes attached to the idea of practice regarding the five eyes and the six supernatural powers;

If one becomes attached to the idea of practice regarding the knowledge of nonforgetting, and the nature of constant relinquishment;
If one becomes attached to the idea of practice regarding omniscience, the cognition of the aspects of the path, and the cognition of all aspects;
If one becomes attached to the idea of practice regarding all dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways;
If one becomes attached to the idea of practice regarding all samÄdhi gateways;
If one becomes attached to the idea of practice regarding the fruit of stream-entry, the fruit of once-returning, the fruit of non-returning, and the fruit of arhatship;
If one becomes attached to the idea of practice regarding the enlightenment of a pratyekabuddha;
If one becomes attached to the idea of practice regarding all the practices of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas;
If one becomes attached to the idea of practice regarding the unsurpassed perfect enlightenment of buddhas.
ÅšÄriputra!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, if they lack skillful means and use something that can be attained as skillful means, giving rise to these various kinds of thoughts is called being attached to characteristics.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
Previously you asked, 'How do Bodhisattva-MahÄsattvas, when practicing prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, avoid attachment to characteristics?'
ÅšÄriputra!
When Bodhisattva-MahÄsattvas practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they skillfully give rise to the thought of emptiness and non-emptiness in form, and also in feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness;
they give rise to the thought of emptiness and non-emptiness in the eye sense base, and also in the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases;
they give rise to the thought of emptiness and non-emptiness in the form sense base, and also in the sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharma sense bases;

they give rise to the thought of emptiness and non-emptiness in the eye element, and also in the form element, eye consciousness element, eye contact, and the feelings produced from eye contact as a condition;

In the ear-element, they do not have the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness, and in the sound-element, ear-consciousness-element, and ear-contact, and in the feelings that arise from ear-contact as a condition, they also do not have the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness. In the nose-element, they do not have the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness, and in the smell-element, nose-consciousness-element, and nose-contact, and in the feelings that arise from nose-contact as a condition, they also do not have the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness;

In the tongue-element, they do not have the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness, and in the taste-element, tongue-consciousness-element, and tongue-contact, and in the feelings that arise from tongue-contact as a condition, they also do not have the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness;

In the body-element, they do not have the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness, and in the touch-element, body-consciousness-element, and body-contact, and in the feelings that arise from body-contact as a condition, they also do not have the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness;

In the mind-element, they do not have the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness, and in the dharma-element, mind-consciousness-element, and mind-contact, and in the feelings that arise from mind-contact as a condition, they also do not have the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness;

In the earth element, do not give rise to the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness, and in the water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements, also do not give rise to the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness;

In ignorance, do not give rise to the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness, and in karmic formations, consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, becoming, birth, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress, also do not give rise to the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness;

In the perfection of generosity, do not give rise to the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness, and in the perfections of morality, patience, diligence, concentration, and wisdom, also do not give rise to the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness;

Regarding internal emptiness, they do not give rise to the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness, and regarding external emptiness, internal and external emptiness, emptiness of emptiness, great emptiness, ultimate emptiness, emptiness of conditioned phenomena, emptiness of unconditioned phenomena, absolute emptiness, emptiness without beginning or end, emptiness of non-dispersal, emptiness of inherent existence, emptiness of specific characteristics, emptiness of general characteristics, emptiness of all phenomena, emptiness of non-apprehension, emptiness of intrinsic nature, emptiness of intrinsic nature of non-existence, and emptiness of the intrinsic nature of non-existence of intrinsic nature, they also do not give rise to the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness;ğŸ”½Regarding suchness, they do not give rise to the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness, and regarding the dharma realm, dharma nature, non-false nature, unchanging nature, equality nature, nature of non-arising, dharma determination, dharma abode, reality limit, space realm, and inconceivable realm, they also do not give rise to the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness;

Regarding the noble truth of suffering, they do not give rise to the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness, and regarding the noble truths of the accumulation, cessation, and path of suffering, they also do not give rise to the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness;
In the four formless concentrations, they do not give rise to the notion of empty or not empty;

In the eight liberations, they do not give rise to the notion of empty or not empty; in the eight superior realms, nine successive concentrations, and ten universal bases, they also do not give rise to the notion of empty or not empty;

In the four establishments of mindfulness, they do not give rise to the notion of empty or not empty; in the four right efforts, four bases of supernatural power, five faculties, five powers, seven factors of enlightenment, and eightfold noble path, they also do not give rise to the notion of empty or not empty;

In the gate of liberation of emptiness, they do not give rise to the notion of empty or not empty; in the gate of liberation of signlessness and wishlessness, they also do not give rise to the notion of empty or not empty;
In the ten grounds of the bodhisattva, they do not give rise to the notion of empty or not empty;
In the five eyes, they do not give rise to the notion of empty or not empty; in the six supernatural powers, they also do not give rise to the notion of empty or not empty;

They do not form the notion of empty or not empty regarding the ten powers of the Buddha, and they also do not form the notion of empty or not empty regarding the four fearlessnesses, four unimpeded understandings, great kindness, great compassion, great joy, great equanimity, and eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha;

They do not form the notion of empty or not empty regarding the factor of extinction devoid of destruction, and they also do not form the notion of empty or not empty regarding the nature of relinquishment that is always present;

They do not form the notion of empty or not empty regarding omniscience, and they also do not form the notion of empty or not empty regarding the cognition of the path and the cognition of all aspects;
They do not form the notion of empty or not empty regarding all dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways, and they also do not form the notion of empty or not empty regarding all samÄdhi gateways;

They do not form the notion of empty or not empty regarding the fruit of entering the stream, and they also do not form the notion of empty or not empty regarding the fruits of the once-returner, non-returner, and arhat;
They do not form the notion of empty or not empty regarding the enlightenment of a pratyekabuddha;
They do not give rise to the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness regarding the practices of all bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas;
They do not give rise to the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness regarding the unsurpassed perfect enlightenment of all buddhas;
They do not give rise to the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness regarding past dharmas, and they do not give rise to the notion of emptiness or non-emptiness regarding future or present dharmas.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, using non-apprehension as skillful means, they do not think like this:
'I can practice giving and bestow it upon the recipient, and this is the nature of giving.'
They do not think like this:
'I can uphold precepts, and these are the precepts to be upheld.'
They do not think like this:
'I can cultivate patience, and this is the patience to be cultivated.'
They do not think like this:
'I can be diligent, and this is the diligence to be practiced.'
They do not think like this:
'I can enter concentration, and this is the concentration to be entered.'
They do not think like this:
'I can cultivate wisdom, this is the wisdom cultivated.'
They do not think like this:
'I can plant blessings, these are the blessings planted and the fruits obtained.'
They do not think like this:
'I can enter the correct nature of detachment of the bodhisattvas.'
They do not think like this:
'I can bring sentient beings to maturity.'
They do not think like this:
'I can adorn and purify the Buddha lands.'
They do not think like this:
'I can realize the cognition of all knowledge.'
They do not think like this:
'I can abide in emptiness and realize the true nature of dharmas.'
They do not think like this:
'I can cultivate the practices of the bodhisattvas.'
They do not think like this:
'I can fully realize the merits of the Buddhas.'
ÅšÄriputra!

If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have skillful means, and practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ with non-apprehension as their skillful means, they will not have any of these discriminations, false thoughts, or attachments, because they thoroughly understand internal emptiness, external emptiness, internal and external emptiness, the emptiness of emptiness, great emptiness, ultimate emptiness, the emptiness of conditioned phenomena, the emptiness of unconditioned phenomena, absolute emptiness, emptiness without beginning or end, dispersed emptiness, emptiness of unchanging nature, emptiness of inherent characteristics, emptiness of common characteristics, emptiness of all phenomena, emptiness of non-apprehension, emptiness of nature, emptiness of inherent nature, and emptiness of the inherent nature of non-existence.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called the skillful means of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practicing prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, with non-apprehension as their skillful means and without the characteristics of attachment.
At that time, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, asked SubhÅ«ti:
Venerable One!
How do the sons and daughters of good family who abide in the vehicle of bodhisattvas and practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ become attached to characteristics?
SubhÅ«ti replied:
KauÅ›ika!

The sons and daughters of good family who abide in the vehicle of bodhisattvas and practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, without skillful means, with attainment as their skillful means, give rise to the thought of attachment;
They give rise to the thought of attachment to the perfection of giving, and give rise to the thought of attachment to the perfection of morality, patience, vigor, meditation, and wisdom;

They give rise to the notion of internal emptiness and become attached to it, and give rise to the notions of external emptiness, internal and external emptiness, empty emptiness, great emptiness, ultimate emptiness, conditioned emptiness, unconditioned emptiness, absolute emptiness, endless emptiness, dispersed emptiness, unchanging emptiness, inherent emptiness, specific emptiness, common emptiness, emptiness of all phenomena, emptiness of non-apprehension, nature emptiness, self-nature emptiness, and emptiness of the nature of non-existence, and become attached to them;

They give rise to the notion of suchness and become attached to it, and give rise to the notions of the dharma realm, dharma nature, non-false nature, unchanging nature, equality nature, nature of detachment from birth, dharma determination, dharma abiding, reality limit, space realm, and inconceivable realm, and become attached to them;
They give rise to the notion of the noble truth of suffering and become attached to it, and give rise to the notions of the noble truths of the accumulation, cessation, and path of suffering;

They give rise to the notion of the four concentrations and become attached to it, and give rise to the notions of the four immeasurable [minds] and four formless concentrations and become attached to them;

They give rise to the notion of attachment to the eight liberations, and give rise to the notion of attachment to the eight superior powers, the nine sequential concentrations, and the ten universal bases;

They give rise to the notion of attachment to the four establishments of mindfulness, and give rise to the notion of attachment to the four right efforts, the four bases of supernatural power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven factors of enlightenment, and the eightfold noble path;

They give rise to the notion of attachment to the door of liberation of emptiness, and give rise to the notion of attachment to the door of liberation of signlessness and the door of liberation of wishlessness;
They give rise to the notion of attachment to the ten grounds of the bodhisattva;
They give rise to the notion of attachment to the five eyes, and give rise to the notion of attachment to the six supernatural powers;

They give rise to the notion of attachment to the ten powers of the Buddha, and give rise to the notion of attachment to the four fearlessnesses, the four unobstructed understandings, great kindness, great compassion, great joy, great equanimity, and the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha;
They give rise to the notion of attachment to the factor of non-forgetting, and give rise to the notion of attachment to the nature of constant relinquishment;
They give rise to the notion of attachment to omniscience, and give rise to the notion of attachment to the cognition of the path and the cognition of all aspects;
They give rise to attachment to the thought of all dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways, and give rise to attachment to the thought of all samÄdhi gateways;

They give rise to attachment to the thought of the fruit of stream-entry, and give rise to attachment to the thought of the fruit of once-returning, the fruit of non-returning, and the fruit of arhatship;
They give rise to attachment to the thought of pratyekabuddha enlightenment;
They give rise to attachment to the thought of all the practices of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas;
They give rise to attachment to the thought of the unsurpassed perfect enlightenment of all buddhas;
They give rise to attachment to the thought of all bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas;
They give rise to attachment to the thought of all tathÄgatas, arhats, perfectly enlightened ones;
They give rise to attachment to the thought of planting various wholesome roots in the Buddha;
They give rise to attachment to the thought of combining those wholesome roots that have been planted and dedicating them to unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment.
KauÅ›ika!

This is called the conceptualization of those sons and daughters of good family who abide in the vehicle of bodhisattvas, who lack skillful means, whose skillful means are based on attainment, and who practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
KauÅ›ika!

Because those sons and daughters of good family who abide in the vehicle of bodhisattvas, due to attachment, are unable to practice the non-attached prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ and dedicate it to unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Why is it so?
KauÅ›ika!
Because the intrinsic nature of form cannot be dedicated, and the intrinsic nature of feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness cannot be dedicated;
Because the intrinsic nature of the eye sense base cannot be dedicated, and the intrinsic nature of the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases cannot be dedicated;
Because the intrinsic nature of the form sense base cannot be dedicated, and the intrinsic nature of the sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharma sense bases cannot be dedicated;

Because the intrinsic nature of the eye element cannot be dedicated, and the intrinsic nature of the form element, eye consciousness element, eye contact, and the feelings produced from eye contact as a condition cannot be dedicated;

Because the intrinsic nature of the ear sense base cannot be dedicated, and the intrinsic nature of the sound sense base, ear consciousness sense base, ear contact, and the feelings that arise from ear contact cannot be dedicated;

Because the intrinsic nature of the nose sense base cannot be dedicated, and the intrinsic nature of the smell sense base, nose consciousness sense base, nose contact, and the feelings that arise from nose contact cannot be dedicated;

Because the intrinsic nature of the tongue sense base cannot be dedicated, and the intrinsic nature of the taste sense base, tongue consciousness sense base, tongue contact, and the feelings that arise from tongue contact cannot be dedicated;

Because the intrinsic nature of the body sense base cannot be dedicated, and the intrinsic nature of the touch sense base, body consciousness sense base, body contact, and the feelings that arise from body contact cannot be dedicated;

Because the intrinsic nature of the mind sense base cannot be dedicated, and the intrinsic nature of the dharma sense base, mind consciousness sense base, mind contact, and the feelings that arise from mind contact cannot be dedicated;
because the intrinsic nature of the earth element cannot be dedicated, and the intrinsic nature of the water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements cannot be dedicated;

because the intrinsic nature of ignorance cannot be dedicated, and the intrinsic nature of karmic formations, consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, becoming, birth, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, distress, and anguish cannot be dedicated.
KauÅ›ika!

because the intrinsic nature of the perfection of giving cannot be dedicated, and the intrinsic nature of the perfections of morality, patience, diligence, concentration, and wisdom cannot be dedicated;

Because the essential nature of internal emptiness cannot be dedicated, and the essential natures of external emptiness, internal and external emptiness, emptiness of emptiness, great emptiness, ultimate emptiness, emptiness of conditioned phenomena, emptiness of unconditioned phenomena, absolute emptiness, emptiness without beginning or end, emptiness of non-dispersal, emptiness of immutability, emptiness of essential nature, emptiness of specific characteristics, emptiness of common characteristics, emptiness of all phenomena, emptiness of non-attainment, emptiness of nature, emptiness of self-nature, and emptiness of the essential nature of non-existence cannot be dedicated;ğŸ”½Because the essential nature of suchness cannot be dedicated, and the essential natures of the dharma realm, dharma nature, non-false nature, non-differentiation nature, equality nature, nature of non-arising, dharma determination, dharma abode, reality limit, space realm, and inconceivable realm cannot be dedicated;

Because the essential nature of the noble truth of suffering cannot be dedicated, and the essential natures of the noble truths of the accumulation, cessation, and path of suffering cannot be dedicated;
because the essential nature of the four formless concentrations is not able to be dedicated,

because the essential nature of the eight liberations is not able to be dedicated, and the essential nature of the eight superior [spheres of] perception, nine successive [stages of] samÄdhi, and ten universal bases is not able to be dedicated,

because the essential nature of the four establishments of mindfulness is not able to be dedicated, and the essential nature of the four right efforts, four bases of supernatural power, five faculties, five powers, seven factors of enlightenment, and eightfold noble path is not able to be dedicated,
because the essential nature of the emptiness liberation gate is not able to be dedicated, and the essential nature of the signless and wishless liberation gates is not able to be dedicated,
because the essential nature of the ten bodhisattva grounds is not able to be dedicated,
because the essential nature of the five eyes is not able to be dedicated, and the essential nature of the six supernatural powers is not able to be dedicated,

because the intrinsic nature of the ten powers of a buddha cannot be dedicated, and the intrinsic nature of the four fearlessnesses, four unobstructed understandings, great kindness, great compassion, great joy, great equanimity, and eighteen distinctive abilities of a buddha cannot be dedicated;
because the intrinsic nature of the absence of forgetfulness cannot be dedicated, and the intrinsic nature of the constant abiding in equanimity cannot be dedicated;
because the intrinsic nature of omniscience cannot be dedicated, and the intrinsic nature of the cognition of the path and the cognition of all aspects cannot be dedicated;
because the intrinsic nature of all dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways cannot be dedicated, and the intrinsic nature of all samÄdhi gateways cannot be dedicated;
because the intrinsic nature of the fruit of entering the stream cannot be dedicated, and the intrinsic nature of the fruits of the once-returner, non-returner, and arhat cannot be dedicated;
because the intrinsic nature of pratyekabuddha enlightenment cannot be dedicated;
because the intrinsic nature of all the practices of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas cannot be dedicated;
Because the essential nature of unsurpassed perfect enlightenment cannot be dedicated.
Furthermore, KauÅ›ika!

If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas wish to demonstrate, teach, exhort, and delight other beings in unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, they should demonstrate, teach, exhort, and delight with the mind of suchness.
And they should demonstrate, teach, exhort, and delight in this way: When practicing the perfection of giving, one should not discriminate that one is able to give;

When practicing the perfection of pure precepts, one should not discriminate that one is able to guard the precepts;ğŸ”½When practicing the perfection of patience, one should not discriminate that one is able to cultivate patience;
When practicing the perfection of vigor, one should not discriminate that one is able to be vigorous;
When practicing the perfection of concentration, one should not discriminate that one is able to enter concentration;
When practicing prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, one should not discriminate that one can cultivate wisdom.
When practicing internal emptiness, one should not discriminate that one can abide in internal emptiness;

when practicing external emptiness, internal and external emptiness, emptiness of emptiness, great emptiness, ultimate emptiness, emptiness of conditioned phenomena, emptiness of unconditioned phenomena, absolute emptiness, emptiness without beginning or end, emptiness of dispersion, emptiness of immutability, emptiness of inherent nature, emptiness of specific characteristics, emptiness of common characteristics, emptiness of all phenomena, emptiness of non-attainment, emptiness of nature, emptiness of self-nature, and emptiness of the nature of selflessness, one should not discriminate that one can abide in external emptiness up to the emptiness of the nature of selflessness.
When practicing suchness, one should not discriminate that one can abide in suchness;

When practicing the dharma realm, dharma nature, non-false nature, unchanging nature, equality nature, separation from birth nature, dharma determination, dharma abode, ultimate reality, space realm, and inconceivable realm, one should not discriminate that one can abide in the dharma realm up to the inconceivable realm.
When practicing the noble truth of suffering, one should not discriminate that one can abide in the noble truth of suffering;
when practicing the noble truths of accumulation, cessation, and the path, one should not discriminate that one can abide in the noble truths of accumulation, cessation, and the path.
When practicing the four meditations, one should not discriminate that one can cultivate the four meditations;
when practicing the four immeasurable [minds] and four formless concentrations, one should not discriminate that one can cultivate the four immeasurable [minds] and four formless concentrations.
When practicing the eight liberations, one should not discriminate that one can cultivate the eight liberations;

When practicing the eight liberations, nine successive concentrations, and ten universal bases, one should not discriminate, thinking 'I am cultivating the eight liberations, nine successive concentrations, and ten universal bases.'
When practicing the four establishments of mindfulness, one should not discriminate, thinking 'I am cultivating the four establishments of mindfulness';

when practicing the four right efforts, four bases of supernatural power, five faculties, five powers, seven factors of enlightenment, and eightfold noble path, one should not discriminate, thinking 'I am cultivating the four right efforts up to the eightfold noble path.'
When practicing the emptiness liberation gate, one should not discriminate, thinking 'I am cultivating the emptiness liberation gate';
when practicing the signless and wishless liberation gates, one should not discriminate, thinking 'I am cultivating the signless and wishless liberation gates.'
When practicing the ten bodhisattva grounds, one should not discriminate, thinking 'I am cultivating the ten bodhisattva grounds';
when practicing the five eyes, one should not discriminate, thinking 'I am cultivating the five eyes';
When practicing the six supernormal powers, one should not discriminate, thinking, I can cultivate the six supernormal powers.
When practicing the ten powers of a Buddha, one should not discriminate, thinking, I can cultivate the ten powers of a Buddha;

when practicing the four forms of fearlessness, the four forms of unobstructed understanding, great kindness, great compassion, great joy, great equanimity, and the eighteen distinctive abilities unique to a Buddha, one should not discriminate, thinking, I can cultivate the four forms of fearlessness up to the eighteen distinctive abilities unique to a Buddha.
When practicing the quality of being free from forgetfulness, one should not discriminate, thinking, I can cultivate the quality of being free from forgetfulness;
when practicing the nature of always maintaining equanimity, one should not discriminate, thinking, I can cultivate the nature of always maintaining equanimity.
When practicing omniscience, one should not discriminate, thinking, I can cultivate omniscience;
when practicing the cognition of the path and the cognition of all aspects, one should not discriminate, thinking, I can cultivate the cognition of the path and the cognition of all aspects.
When practicing all dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways, one should not discriminate, thinking 'I am cultivating all dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways';
when practicing all samÄdhi gateways, one should not discriminate, thinking 'I am cultivating all samÄdhi gateways.'
When practicing the similar dharmas of the fruit of stream-entry, one should not discriminate, thinking 'I am cultivating the similar dharmas of the fruit of stream-entry';

when practicing the similar dharmas of the fruits of once-returning, non-returning, and arhatship, one should not discriminate, thinking 'I am cultivating the similar dharmas of the fruits of once-returning, non-returning, and arhatship.'
When practicing the similar dharmas of pratyekabuddha enlightenment, one should not discriminate, thinking 'I am cultivating the similar dharmas of pratyekabuddha enlightenment.'
When practicing all the practices of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, one should not discriminate, thinking 'I am cultivating all the practices of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.'
When practicing the unsurpassed perfect enlightenment of all buddhas, one should not discriminate, thinking 'I am cultivating the unsurpassed perfect enlightenment of all buddhas.'
KauÅ›ika!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should thus demonstrate, teach, encourage, and delight other beings in unsurpassed perfect enlightenment. If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas can thus demonstrate, teach, encourage, and delight other beings in unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, they will not harm themselves, nor will they harm others, because they demonstrate, teach, encourage, and delight other beings as approved by the TathÄgatas.
KauÅ›ika!

If the good men and good women who abide in the vehicle of bodhisattvas can thus demonstrate, teach, encourage, and delight those beings who aspire to the vehicle of bodhisattvas, they will be able to completely avoid all attachments.
At that time, the World-Honored One praised the Venerable SubhÅ«ti, saying:ğŸ”½Excellent!
Excellent!
It is as you have said.
You are now well able to speak for the bodhisattvas about the characteristics of attachment.
SubhÅ«ti!
There are also other subtle attachments that I will now explain for you. You should listen carefully and contemplate well!
SubhÅ«ti said:
Yes!
Please explain!
We wish to hear it.
The Buddha said:
SubhÅ«ti!

Good men and good women who abide in the vehicle of bodhisattvas and wish to attain supreme perfect enlightenment, if they take characteristics and recollect the TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One, it is all attachment;

If they take characteristics and recollect the unattached merits and virtues of all TathÄgatas, Arhats, Perfectly Enlightened Ones of the past, future, and present, from their initial generation of the mind of enlightenment up to the abiding of the Dharma, and after recollecting, dedicate them to supreme perfect enlightenment, all such recollections of characteristics are called attachment;

If one takes characteristics and recollects the wholesome dharmas cultivated by all the disciples of the TathÄgata and other sentient beings, and dedicates them to unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, all of this is also called attachment.
Why is it so?

Because the unattached merit and virtue of all the TathÄgatas, Arhats, and Samyaksaá¹ƒbuddhas should not be taken with characteristics and recollected, and because the wholesome dharmas of the Buddha's disciples and other sentient beings should not be taken with characteristics and recollected, and because all those who take characteristics are all false.
At that time, SubhÅ«ti addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is the most profound.
The Buddha said:
It is so!
Because the inherent nature of all dharmas is empty.
The Venerable SubhÅ«ti further addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ should be revered.
The Buddha said:
It is so!
Because of the abundance of merits, this prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is without creation and without action, and there is no one who can awaken to it.
The Venerable SubhÅ«ti addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
The nature of all dharmas is difficult to awaken to.
The Buddha said:
So it is!
Because all dharmas are of one nature and not two.
SubhÅ«ti!

You should know that the one nature of all dharmas is precisely their naturelessness. The naturelessness of all dharmas is precisely their one nature. Thus, the one nature and naturelessness of all dharmas are without creation and without action. If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas can understand as it truly is that all existing dharmas are of one nature and natureless, without creation and without action, then they will be able to completely abandon all attachments.
The Venerable SubhÅ«ti addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is difficult to understand.
The Buddha said:
So it is!
Because this prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ cannot be seen, heard, cognized, or known by anyone, because it is beyond the characteristics of realization.
The Venerable SubhÅ«ti addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is inconceivable.
The Buddha said:
So it is!
Why is it so?
This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ cannot be known by the mind, because it is beyond the characteristics of the mind.
This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ cannot be known by form, because it is beyond the characteristics of form;
it cannot be known by feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness, because it is beyond the characteristics of feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness.
This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ cannot be known by the eye sense base, because it is beyond the characteristics of the eye sense base;
it cannot be known by the ear, nose, tongue, body, or mind sense bases, because it is beyond the characteristics of the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases.
Thus, this prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ cannot be known through the form aggregate, because it is apart from the characteristics of the form aggregate;
it cannot be known through the sound, smell, taste, touch, or dharmas aggregates, because it is apart from the characteristics of the sound, smell, taste, touch, or dharmas aggregates.
Thus, this prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ cannot be known through the eye element, because it is apart from the characteristics of the eye element;

it cannot be known through the form element, eye consciousness element, eye contact, or the feelings produced from the conditions of eye contact, because it is apart from the characteristics of the form element up to the feelings produced from the conditions of eye contact.
Thus, this prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ cannot be known through the ear element, because it is apart from the characteristics of the ear element;

it cannot be known through the sound element, ear consciousness element, ear contact, or the feelings produced from the conditions of ear contact, because it is apart from the characteristics of the sound element up to the feelings produced from the conditions of ear contact.
Thus, this prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ cannot be known through the nose element, because it is apart from the characteristics of the nose element;

It is because the characteristics of the nose consciousness element, nose contact, and the feelings produced from nose contact as a condition are not to be known apart from the nose contact as a condition.
In this way, prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ cannot be known through the tongue element, because it is apart from the characteristics of the tongue element;

it is because the characteristics of the taste element, tongue consciousness element, and the feelings produced from tongue contact as a condition are not to be known apart from the tongue contact as a condition.

Indra thought to himself:

If good men and good women have already closely attended and made offerings to immeasurable TathÄgatas, Arhats, and Samyaksaá¹ƒbuddhas in the past, made great vows, planted various roots of goodness, and been accepted by many good spiritual friends, they can now hear the name of the merit of such prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ. How much more so for those who are able to write it out, recite it, uphold it, contemplate it according to the principles, expound it for others, or be able to practice it according to the teachings to the best of their abilities!

One should know that this person has already in the past closely attended, served, made offerings, paid respect, revered, praised, and planted various roots of goodness to the Buddhas, and has already heard the perfection of wisdom. Having heard it, they have received and upheld it, contemplated it, recited it, explained it to others, and practiced as taught. Either they have been able to ask questions about this sÅ«tra or have been able to answer them. Due to the power of this merit, they are now able to accomplish this matter.

If good sons and good women have already made offerings to immeasurable TathÄgatas, Arhats, and Samyaksaá¹ƒbuddhas, and their merit is pure, when they hear this perfection of wisdom, their minds will not be startled, frightened, or terrified. Having heard it, they will believe and enjoy it, and practice as taught. One should know that this person has already cultivated the perfections of giving, morality, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom for many koá¹­is of kalpas, and is now able to accomplish this matter.
At that time, the Venerable ÅšÄriputra addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

If good men and good women hear the profound meaning of this prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, their minds are not startled, frightened, or terrified. Having heard it, they write it out, recite it, uphold it, contemplate it according to the principles, expound it for others, or else practice according to the teachings to the best of their abilities. One should know that such people are like the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who are not yet in the stage of nonretrogression.
Why is this?
World-Honored One!

The meaning and purport of such prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is profound and extremely difficult to believe and understand.
